FBI knew of bomber

Russian officials warned feds of Tsarnaev's radical shift in '11

Residents held up American flags during Saturday’s candlelight vigil at Watertown's Victory Park. Jared Wickerham/Getty Images
Fans held a U.S. flag before a baseball game between the Boston Red Sox and the Kansas City Royals. Michael Dwyer/AP Photo
A thermal image released by the Massachusetts State Police Air Wing, showed the boat where Boston Marathon bombing suspect Dzhokhar Tsarnaev hid on April 19. Jared Wickerham/Getty Images
A Watertown resident held up a collection of balloons, each with a name of those killed in the Boston Marathon bombings. Jared Wickerham/Getty Images
Utahns who ran in the Boston Marathon on Monday posed for pictures after running the Salt Lake City marathon at Liberty Park. Chris Detrick/AP Photo
Sarah Vieira, 13, of Dartmouth, had "Boston Strong" written on her face during the Red Sox-Royals game. Michael Dwyer/AP Photo
A woman made a sign during a candlelight vigil in Watertown for victims of the Boston Marathon bombing. Kevork Djansezian/Getty Images
Marathoners Dick Hoyt (right) and his son Rick came onto the field for the ceremonial first pitch before the Red Sox-Royals game. Michael Dwyer/AP Photo
Neil Diamond performed "Sweet Caroline" during the eighth inning of the Red Sox game at Fenway Park. Bob Leonard/AP
Four-year-old Jane Cosmas of Somerville drew a heart amidst hundreds of chalk messages written by passersby about the Boston Marathon bombings on Newbury Street. Jim Bourg/Reuters
"This is our [expletive] city, and nobody is going to dictate our freedom. Stay strong," David Ortiz said when he addressed fans during an emotional pre-game ceremony at Fenway Park. Jessica Rinaldi/Reuters
Fans walked out of Fenway Park after the Boston Red Sox beat the Kansas City Royals, 4-3 Michael Reynolds/EPA
Investigators worked in the boat where Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, 19, was found in Watertown on Friday. Katie Zezima/AP
An image of slain Massachusetts Institute of Technology Police Officer Sean Collier was displayed during a tribute at Fenway Park. Michael Dwyer/AP
A fan displayed a "Believe in Boston" sign outside of Fenway Park. Jim Rogash/Getty Images
Fans held signs to honor the Marathon bombing victims before a game against the Kansas City Royals at Fenway Park Jim Rogash/Getty Images
Evidence technicians continued to search the scene of the Boston Marathon bombings for evidence. Jim Bourg/Reuters
A young girl wrote a message on a sign at a memorial to the victims near the scene of the Boston Marathon bombings. Jim Bourg/Reuters
A vendor sold souvenirs outside Fenway Park before a game between the Red Sox and the Kansas City Royals. Michael Dwyer/AP photo
Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives and FBI agents checked Dzhokhar Tsarnaev for explosives and also gave him medical attention after he was apprehended. AP photo
This image obtained courtesy CBS News shows suspect, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, after he was found hiding in a boat in Watertown, wounded and weary after a gun battle with police Thursday night that left his accomplice brother dead. AFP photo/CBS news
Tamerlan Tsarnaev, third from left, who was dubbed Suspect No. 1 and second from left, Dzhokhar A. Tsarnaev, who was dubbed Suspect No. 2, are pictured 10 to 20 minutes before the bombings at the Boston Marathon. Bob Leonard/AP

FBI warned about suspect in 2011

The news that the FBI was alerted to suspected bomber Tamerlan Tsarnaev's radical shift two years ago is raising questions about whether the attacks were preventable.
  • Was the older suspect the leader?
  • Doctor: Dead bomb suspect had wounds 'head to toe'

Watertown revels in return to normalcy

Across the region, but particularly in besieged Watertown, people fanned out of their homes following an intense lock-down and manhunt.
  • Suburb becomes war zone in days after bombings
  • Pictures Candlelight vigil in Watertown's Victory Field

Victims watched, hurt, now heal together

More than 170 people were injured in the Boston Marathon blasts. Now, some face a fearful future as they look to recovery.

Biden says response to tragedies 'incredible'

Vice President Joe Biden on Saturday said the strength of those devastated by the Boston Marathon bombing and other recent tragedies is remarkable and proof that some good can come from carnage and pain.
watch

Ex-teacher: 'They were normal people here'

Residents of a village in Kyrgyzstan where the two bombing suspects once lived are in disbelief at the turn their lives have taken.

The five days that shook Boston

This documentary by Globe staff and correspondents chronicles the week of fear that followed the Boston Marathon bombings.

Bomb suspect hospitalized under heavy guard

Boston Marathon bombing suspect Dzhokhar Tsarnaev lay hospitalized in serious condition under heavy guard Saturday — apparently in no shape to be interrogated — as investigators tried to establish the motive for the deadly attack and the scope of the plot.
  • BPD Commissioner: Releasing photos was 'turning point'
  • Watch Suspect captured | Capture brings relief | Neighbors react

After Boston, London Marathon moves forward

Less than a week after the Boston Marathon bombings, London will rely on lessons learned from its own tragic past as it prepares to host 36,500 runners and an estimated 700,000 spectators.
  • London Marathon runners show spirit, support for Boston

Researchers urge brain autopsy of suspect

Two pioneering researchers of brain disease recommended that investigators conduct autopsy tests on Tamerlan Tsarnaev to determine whether the Boston Marathon bombing suspect could have been affected by boxing-related brain damage.

Lawmaker's 'torture' tweet spurs controversy

A New York state senator sparked a controversy online by asking in a tweet if the Boston Marathon bombing suspect should be tortured.
